content: Added "write answer" to stub generator so that the initial default code shows the syntax for debugging and outputting the answer.

Nice puzzle!
Wouldn't it be nice to keep an infinite tape?
I mean, you just need to assume that the machine halts and let the programers handle the tape.

ValNykol, great puzzle! Only one problem which I spotted, you mentioned in your description to print T if the head goes out of bounds towards the right, but none of your "out of bound right" testcases expect that. 

Once you fix this I approve :)

There weren't any puzzles involving a Turing machine, so I thought I should add one. Couldn't think of anything fancy, just a simple simulation for a simple model.
Let me know if the description isn't clear or if there are any issues with the validators. Also, suggestions are welcome!
T is a variable - the number of cells on the tape. It is the second integer in the input. Though I guess it may be confusing, so I'll add a note.

It's an interesting idea, but I wanted to include some simple infinitely-looping machines. And it's not possible to keep both, because there is no way to detect infinite loops for the general case (it's the halting problem).
So I decided to stick to fixed-size tape but allow infinite loops that will go out of bounds.

Hum ok. I see the point, either you handle the possible grow of the tape or you handle the case where the head goes out of the tape.
It is a matter of taste, but I find the first case more interesting/challenging.
In any case, it is already a good puzzle :)
That does sound a bit confusing but does make sense, fair enough. I will approve of this.
